conclusion: Liquid flows out from points A, B, C, and D and needs to be determined which container—E, F, or G—it will flow into after passing through baffles.
Setup includes four input points: A, B, C, and D, three output containers: E, F, and G, and some baffles or obstacles.
Liquid flows from inputs through baffles into one of the containers.
Visualizing positions of A, B, C, D relative to E, F, and G with inputs possibly at the top and containers at the bottom.
Liquid flows along the path of least resistance to the containers.
Baffles may direct the flow in specific ways, potentially blocking direct paths.
Approach involves tracing the path for each input separately.
Consideration of barriers preventing liquid from reaching specific containers.
Flow from each input is assumed to be independent.
Without baffles, liquid would flow directly downward to containers.
Baffles may guide liquid towards specific containers.
Image shows input points A, B, C, D at the top and containers E, F, G at the bottom with baffles in between.
Baffles are positioned diagonally across the path from inputs to containers.
Container E is positioned at the bottom left, container F in the middle, and container G at the bottom right.
Baffles are colored black, yellow, white, and gray.
Containers E, F, and G are colored green, red, and white respectively.
